article.title: Sex differences in muscle health in simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments in rats
article.abstract: Skeletal muscle size and strength are important for overall health for astronauts. However, how male and female muscle may respond differently to micro- and partial-gravity environments is not fully understood.

sections.introduction: Skeletal muscle strength is critical for operational health and safety for astronauts upon the International Space Station and future missions to the Moon and Mars.
sections.methods: Overall design: All experimental procedures were approved by the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC, protocol number: 081–2020).
sections.results: F-SHAM-0g had similar bodyweight losses compared to M-SHAM-0g (Fig. 1A).
sections.discussion: Our study builds on prior research in this domain8, 9, 10, 11 and concurs with prior literature finding females appear more susceptible to disuse atrophy relative to males.

article.insights_summary: Our study found that females experience greater relative loss across various components of muscle health in simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments, including muscle size and muscle strength, compared to males.
article.acknowledgments: This study was funded by NASA Awards: 80NSSC21K0311 (M.E.R./S.B.R) and 80NSSC19K1598 (S.B,R.) as well as NIH Award: R37HD019938 (U.B.K.), and T32GM144273 (A.W.)
